awd_titl_txt: Random Matrices, Spin Glass, and Interacting Particle Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Many physical phenomena are modeled as particles interacting randomly. Moving cars in one-lane traffic are one of such examples. Sometimes the interactions of the particles in a small area have a lasting influence on the far away location over time. It is of great interest to find out how fast such influence spreads. This project is concerned with some of the fundamental questions on the spread of local random interactions on a global scale for a class of random processes. The project provides research training opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students.

In more concrete terms, the investigator will perform research on spin glass, interacting particle systems, and random growth models with a focus on the fluctuations of large systems. In particular, the investigator will study the free energy and overlaps of the two-spin spherical Sherrington-Kirkpatrick model with critically-tuned external field, the random field for periodic KPZ universality class, and also the last passage time for a class of directed percolation models. There are deep connections to random matrix theory which the investigator will utilize and also expand. The exactly solvable nature of the models will also be used in the research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project explored large-dimensional systems characterized by random interactions among their components, focusing on three primary models: spin glasses, interacting particle systems, and random matrices. The principal investigator (PI) examined the behavior of these systems as their size increases and the role of randomness in their dynamics.

In the spin glass domain, the PI investigated the spherical variant of the Sherrington-Kirkpatrick model under the influence of an external field. This research involved calculating three types of overlaps of randomly chosen spins, which measure their proximity to a selected vector. The project yielded detailed results across nearly all temperatures and external field strengths.

For the interacting particle systems, the project analyzed a simplified one-lane traffic model configured in a ring and compared it to an infinite line scenario. This work uncovered fundamental probabilistic properties related to large system limits in this context.

Finally, the project delved into the eigenvalues of random matrices, with a particular focus on the real Ginibre ensemble. The PI established an innovative connection between the largest eigenvalue in the thinning regime and a system of well-known differential equations from integrable systems theory.

In addition to these mathematical advancements, the project also fostered the development and career progression of several junior researchers, graduate students, and postdoctoral scholars.

 


Last Modified: 09/24/2024
Modified by: Jinho Baik
